But as the unconventional battle waged on, he began to think that the culture of keeping important information classified was misguided and actually counterproductive. In a short but powerful talk McChrystal makes the case for actively sharing knowledge.", "event": "TED2014", "language": "en", "language_swap": false, "name": "Stanley McChrystal: The military case for sharing knowledge", "slug": "stanley_mcchrystal_the_military_case_for_sharing_knowledge", "series_slug": null, "speakers": [{"id": "924", "slug": "stanley_mcchrystal", "is_published": true, "firstname": "Stanley", "lastname": "McChrystal", "middleinitial": "", "title": "General", "description": "Military leader", "photo_url": "https://pe.tedcdn.com/images/ted/b59beb0dd37c82b276334715843cb098f70f0746_254x191.jpg", "whatotherssay": "One of America\u2019s greatest warriors.", "whotheyare": "General Stanley McChrystal is the former commander of U.S. and International forces in Afghanistan. A four-star general, he is credited for creating a revolution in warfare that fuses intelligence and operations.", "whylisten": "

With a remarkable record of achievement, General Stanley McChrystal has been praised for creating a revolution in warfare that fused intelligence and operations. A four-star general, he is the former commander of U.S. and international forces in Afghanistan and the former leader of Joint Special Operations Command (JSOC), which oversees the military’s most sensitive forces. McChrystal’s leadership of JSOC is credited with the December 2003 capture of Saddam Hussein and the June 2006 location and killing of Abu Musab al-Zarqawi, the leader of al-Qaeda in Iraq. McChrystal, a former Green Beret, is known for his candor.

After McChrystal graduated from West Point, he was commissioned as an infantry officer, and spent much of his career commanding special operations and airborne infantry units. During the Persian Gulf War, McChrystal served in a Joint Special Operations Task Force and later commanded the 75th Ranger Regiment. He completed year-long fellowships at Harvard’s John F. Kennedy School of Government in 1997 and in 2000 at the Council on Foreign Relations. In 2002, he was appointed chief of staff of military operations in Afghanistan. Two years later, McChrystal was selected to deliver nationally televised Pentagon briefings about military operations in Iraq. From 2003 to 2008, McChrystal commanded JSOC and was responsible for leading the nation’s deployed military counter-terrorism efforts around the globe. He assumed command of all International Forces in Afghanistan in June 2009. President Obama’s order for an additional 30,000 troops to Afghanistan was based on McChrystal’s assessment of the war there. McChrystal retired from the military in August 2010.

A four-star general, he is credited for creating a revolution in warfare that fuses intelligence and operations.", "whylisten": "

With a remarkable record of achievement, General Stanley McChrystal has been praised for creating a revolution in warfare that fused intelligence and operations. A four-star general, he is the former commander of U.S. and international forces in Afghanistan and the former leader of Joint Special Operations Command (JSOC), which oversees the military’s most sensitive forces. McChrystal’s leadership of JSOC is credited with the December 2003 capture of Saddam Hussein and the June 2006 location and killing of Abu Musab al-Zarqawi, the leader of al-Qaeda in Iraq. McChrystal, a former Green Beret, is known for his candor.

After McChrystal graduated from West Point, he was commissioned as an infantry officer, and spent much of his career commanding special operations and airborne infantry units. During the Persian Gulf War, McChrystal served in a Joint Special Operations Task Force and later commanded the 75th Ranger Regiment. He completed year-long fellowships at Harvard’s John F. Kennedy School of Government in 1997 and in 2000 at the Council on Foreign Relations. In 2002, he was appointed chief of staff of military operations in Afghanistan. Two years later, McChrystal was selected to deliver nationally televised Pentagon briefings about military operations in Iraq. From 2003 to 2008, McChrystal commanded JSOC and was responsible for leading the nation’s deployed military counter-terrorism efforts around the globe. He assumed command of all International Forces in Afghanistan in June 2009. President Obama’s order for an additional 30,000 troops to Afghanistan was based on McChrystal’s assessment of the war there. McChrystal retired from the military in August 2010.

author: Stanley_McChrystal;
title: The military case for sharing knowledge

aws-transcripts.transcript: When I was a young officer, they told me to follow my instincts to go with my gut, and what I'd learned is it. Often our instincts are wrong. In the summer of 2010 there was a massive leak of classified documents that came out of the Pentagon. It shocked the world. It shook up the American government, and it made people ask a lot of questions because the mere amount of information that was let out and the potential impacts were significant. One of the first questions we asked ourselves was, Why would a young soldier have access to that much information? Why would we let sensitive things be with a relatively young person? In the summer of 2003 I was assigned to command a Special Operations task force and that task forces spread across the Mideast to fight Al Qaeda. Our main effort was inside Iraq, and our specified mission was to defeat Al Qaeda in Iraq. For almost five years, I stayed there and we focused on fighting a war that was unconventional and it was difficult and it was bloody, and it often claimed its highest price among innocent people. We did everything we could to stop Al Qaeda and the foreign fighters that came in a suicide bombers and his accelerants to the violence. We honed our combat skills. We developed new equipment. We parachuted, we helicoptered, we took small boats, we drove and we walked two objectives night after night to to stop the killing that this network was putting forward. We bled, we died and we killed to stop that organization from the violence that they were putting largely against the Iraqi people. Now we did what we knew, how we had grown up in one of the things that we knew that was in our d N A. With secrecy. It was security was protecting information was the idea that information was the life blood and it was what would protect and keep people safe. And we had a sense that as we operated within our organizations, it was important to keep information in the silos within the organization, particularly on Lee. Give information to people who had a demonstrated need to know. But the question often came. Who needs to know who needed who had to have the information so they could do the important parts of the job that you needed in an n tightly coupled world, that's very hard to predict. It's very hard to know who needs to have information and who doesn't. I used to deal with intelligence agencies, and I complained that they weren't sharing enough intelligence and with a straight face and looking and they'd say, What aren't you getting? He said. If I knew that, we wouldn't have a problem. What we found is we had to change. We had to change our culture about information. We had to knock down the walls. We had to share. We had to change from Who needs to know to the fact that who doesn't know and we need to tell and tell them as quickly as we can? It was a significant culture shift for an organization that had secrecy in its D. N. A. We started by doing things by building, not working in offices, knocking down walls, working and things we called Situation Awareness Room and and in the summer of 2007 something happened which demonstrated this week captured the personnel records for the people who are bringing foreign fighters into Iraq, and when we got the personal records. Typically, we would we would have hidden these, shared them with a few intelligence agencies and then tried to operate with him. But I was talking to my intelligence officer said What do we do it? He said, Well, you found him our command You can just declassify him and I said, Well, can we declassify? And what if the enemy finds out? He says they're their personnel records. So we did. A lot of people got upset about that. But as we pass that information around, suddenly you find that information's on Leah value. If you give it to people in the ability to do something with it. The fact that I know something has zero value if I'm not the person who can actually make something better because of it. So as a consequence, what we did was we change The idea of information instead of knowledge is power the one we're sharing his power. It was the fundamental shift, not new tactics, not new weapons, not knew anything else. It was the idea that we were now part of a team which information became the essential link between us, not a block between us. Now I want everybody to sort of take a deep breath and then let it out. Because in your life there's gonna be information that leaks out. You're not gonna like somebody's going to get my college grades out. That's gonna be a disaster. But it's gonna be okay. And I will tell you that I am more scared of the bureaucrat that holds information in a desk drawer or a safe than I am of someone who leaks because ultimately will be better off if we share. Thank you. I don't know if you were here this morning. If you were able to catch Rick Ledgett, the deputy director of the NSA, who was astounding to Edward Snowden talk earlier this week. I just wonder, Do you think the American government should give Edward Snowden amnesty? I think that Rick said something very important. We most people don't know all the facts. I think there are two parts of this. Edward Snowden shined a light on an important need that people had to understand. He also took a lot of documents that he didn't have the knowledge to know the importance of. So I think we need to learn the facts about this case before we make snap judgments about 100 stone. Thank you, Theo.
